Description: Cypriot terracotta figure of horse-and-rider. Handmade horseman in primitive style. Fragment of horses head, tall neck with high mane, chest, top of front legs and riders hands. Very broken and worn, missing end of horses snout. Much of the outer surface is eroded and as a result there is no trace of paint. Pale pink-buff fabric with abundant sub angular coarse white (shelly limestone) and black (basic volcanic) inclusions. Sparse red inclusions that may be grog.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Sanctuary of Apollo (Naukratis), Stratum AΠ2 ('bothros' / 'trench with bowls')
Curator's comments: This very stylised type with a high mane and long neck belongs to the beginning of the Archaic II period, probably the early 6th century BC, or possibly earlier (see GR 1876,0909.95). Parallels from Amathus and Ayios Therapon (Karageorghis 1995, pl.37.5 2(i)c.1, pl. 40.1 2(i)c.24, pl.44.10 2(i)c.65). For fabric see (ibid. pl.13.4-6, G22-24). Karageorghis, V. 1995. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro-Archaic Period small male figurines. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.051) (Phase 1)
